newsitem.title: USA: Coors says sees stable costs for 1997.
newsitem.headline: Coors says sees stable costs for 1997.

text.p: Adolph Coors Cos said it sees stable costs for the rest of 1997 and competitive selling as the company moves into its peak season.
"We are particularly pleased to start strong in 1997 and move into the peak summer selling season with solid trends in our core business," said vice chairman Peter Coors.

"Our two largest brands continued to build sales momentum in the first quarter, as Coors Light and Original Coors both delivered strong growth, and we continue to be encouraged by the significant revenue and profit contributions of our international business," he said.
"Overall, we believe we have the elements in place to achieve positive performance this summer and for the full year," he added.

W. Leo Kiely III, president and chief operating officer, said, "The cost picture for the balance of 1997 appears fairly stable, but we see a very competitive selling situation as we move into our peak season. This challenging market environment is characterized by very aggressive multi-pack and pricing activity in several key markets."

Coors said its expenses related to its settlement with Molson Breweries will affect Adolph Coors Company's second quarter results. On April 16 Molson Breweries of Canada and announced the signing of a conditional agreement for a new venture to manage Coors brands in Canada. Under the settlement terms, Molson Breweries paid Coors Can $100 million (approximately US$72 million).

Coors Co Thursday said for the 13-week quarter ended March 30, 1997, the company reported net sales of $399.0 million, a 7.4 percent increase from $371.7 million a year earlier. Net income was $8.0 million, or $0.21 per share, a significant increase from a $3.0 million net loss, or $0.08 per share loss, in the 1996 first quarter.
